trans-unit.source: Optimizing MySQL Performance on Azure Linux VMs
trans-unit.target: Optimizing MySQL Performance on Azure Linux VMs

trans-unit.source: Learn how to optimize MySQL running on an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to optimize MySQL running on an Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux.

trans-unit.source: Optimizing MySQL Performance on Azure Linux VMs
trans-unit.target: Optimizing MySQL Performance on Azure Linux VMs

trans-unit.source: There are many factors that impact MySQL performance on Azure, both in virtual hardware selection and software configuration.
trans-unit.target: There are many factors that impact MySQL performance on Azure, both in virtual hardware selection and software configuration.

trans-unit.source: This article focuses on optimizing performance through storage, system, and database configurations.
trans-unit.target: This article focuses on optimizing performance through storage, system, and database configurations.

trans-unit.source: Utilizing RAID on an Azure virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Utilizing RAID on an Azure virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Storage is the key factor that impacts database performance in cloud environments.
trans-unit.target: Storage is the key factor that impacts database performance in cloud environments.

trans-unit.source: Compared to a single disk, RAID can provide faster access via concurrency.
trans-unit.target: Compared to a single disk, RAID can provide faster access via concurrency.

trans-unit.source: Refer to <link><linkText>Standard RAID Levels</linkText><title></title></link> for more detail.
trans-unit.target: Refer to <link><linkText>Standard RAID Levels</linkText><title></title></link> for more detail.

trans-unit.source: Disk I/O throughput and I/O response time in Azure can be significantly improved through RAID.
trans-unit.target: Disk I/O throughput and I/O response time in Azure can be significantly improved through RAID.

trans-unit.source: Our lab tests show disk I/O throughput can be doubled and I/O response time can be reduced by half on average when the number of RAID disks is doubled (from 2 to 4, 4 to 8, etc.).
trans-unit.target: Our lab tests show disk I/O throughput can be doubled and I/O response time can be reduced by half on average when the number of RAID disks is doubled (from 2 to 4, 4 to 8, etc.).

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Appendix A</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Appendix A</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: In addition to disk I/O, MySQL performance improves when you increase the RAID level.
trans-unit.target: In addition to disk I/O, MySQL performance improves when you increase the RAID level.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: You may also want to consider the chunk size.
trans-unit.target: You may also want to consider the chunk size.

trans-unit.source: In general when you have a larger chunk size, you will get lower overhead, especially for large writes.
trans-unit.target: In general when you have a larger chunk size, you will get lower overhead, especially for large writes.

trans-unit.source: However, when the chunk size is too large, it might add additional overhead and you cannot take advantage of the RAID.
trans-unit.target: However, when the chunk size is too large, it might add additional overhead and you cannot take advantage of the RAID.

trans-unit.source: The current default size is 512KB, which is proven to be optimal for most general production environments.
trans-unit.target: The current default size is 512KB, which is proven to be optimal for most general production environments.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Appendix C</linkText><title></title></link> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Appendix C</linkText><title></title></link> for details.

trans-unit.source: Please note that there are limits on how many disks you can add for different virtual machine types.
trans-unit.target: Please note that there are limits on how many disks you can add for different virtual machine types.

trans-unit.source: These limits are detailed in <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: These limits are detailed in <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You will need 4 attached data disks to follow the RAID example in this article, although you could choose to set up RAID with fewer disks.
trans-unit.target: You will need 4 attached data disks to follow the RAID example in this article, although you could choose to set up RAID with fewer disks.

trans-unit.source: This article assumes you have already created a Linux virtual machine and have MYSQL installed and configured.
trans-unit.target: This article assumes you have already created a Linux virtual machine and have MYSQL installed and configured.

trans-unit.source: For more information on getting started please refer to How to install MySQL on Azure.
trans-unit.target: For more information on getting started please refer to How to install MySQL on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Setting up RAID on Azure
trans-unit.target: Setting up RAID on Azure

trans-unit.source: The following steps show how to create RAID on Azure using the Windows Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to create RAID on Azure using the Windows Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can also set up RAID using Windows PowerShell scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can also set up RAID using Windows PowerShell scripts.

trans-unit.source: In this example we will configure RAID 0 with 4 disks.
trans-unit.target: In this example we will configure RAID 0 with 4 disks.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Add a Data Disk to your Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Add a Data Disk to your Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: In the Virtual Machines page of the Azure Management Portal, click the virtual machine to which you want to add a data disk.
trans-unit.target: In the Virtual Machines page of the Azure Management Portal, click the virtual machine to which you want to add a data disk.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the virtual machine is mysqlnode1.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the virtual machine is mysqlnode1.

trans-unit.source: On the page for the virtual machine, click Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: On the page for the virtual machine, click Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click Attach.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click Attach.

trans-unit.source: And then click Attach empty disk.
trans-unit.target: And then click Attach empty disk.

trans-unit.source: For data disks, the Host Cache Preference should be set to None.
trans-unit.target: For data disks, the Host Cache Preference should be set to None.

trans-unit.source: This will add one empty disk into your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This will add one empty disk into your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this step three more times so that you have 4 data disks for RAID.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this step three more times so that you have 4 data disks for RAID.

trans-unit.source: You can see the added drives in the virtual machine by looking at the kernel message log.
trans-unit.target: You can see the added drives in the virtual machine by looking at the kernel message log.

trans-unit.source: For example, to see this on Ubuntu, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: For example, to see this on Ubuntu, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create RAID with the additional disks
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create RAID with the additional disks

trans-unit.source: Follow this article for detailed RAID setup steps:
trans-unit.target: Follow this article for detailed RAID setup steps:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-linux-configure-RAID/</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-linux-configure-RAID/</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: If you are using the XFS file system, follow the steps below after you have created RAID.

trans-unit.target: Step 3: Set up a new storage path

trans-unit.source: Use the following command:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command:

trans-unit.target: Step 4: Copy the original data to the new storage path

trans-unit.source: Use the following command:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command:

trans-unit.target: Step 5: Modify permissions so MySQL can access (read and write) the data disk

trans-unit.source: Use the following command:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command:

trans-unit.source: Adjust the disk I/O scheduling algorithm
trans-unit.target: Adjust the disk I/O scheduling algorithm

trans-unit.source: Linux implements four types of I/O scheduling algorithms:
trans-unit.target: Linux implements four types of I/O scheduling algorithms:

trans-unit.source: NOOP algorithm (No Operation)
trans-unit.target: NOOP algorithm (No Operation)

trans-unit.source: Deadline algorithm (Deadline)
trans-unit.target: Deadline algorithm (Deadline)

trans-unit.source: Completely fair queuing algorithm (CFQ)
trans-unit.target: Completely fair queuing algorithm (CFQ)

trans-unit.source: Budget period algorithm (Anticipatory)
trans-unit.target: Budget period algorithm (Anticipatory)

trans-unit.source: You can select different I/O schedulers under different scenarios to optimize performance.
trans-unit.target: You can select different I/O schedulers under different scenarios to optimize performance.

trans-unit.source: In a completely random access environment, there is not a big difference between the CFQ and Deadline algorithms for performance.
trans-unit.target: In a completely random access environment, there is not a big difference between the CFQ and Deadline algorithms for performance.

trans-unit.source: It is generally recommended to set the MySQL database environment to Deadline for stability.
trans-unit.target: It is generally recommended to set the MySQL database environment to Deadline for stability.

trans-unit.source: If there is a lot of sequential I/O, CFQ may reduce disk I/O performance.
trans-unit.target: If there is a lot of sequential I/O, CFQ may reduce disk I/O performance.

trans-unit.source: For SSD and other equipment, using NOOP or Deadline can achieve better performance than the Default scheduler.
trans-unit.target: For SSD and other equipment, using NOOP or Deadline can achieve better performance than the Default scheduler.

trans-unit.source: From the kernel 2.5, the default I/O scheduling algorithm is Deadline.
trans-unit.target: From the kernel 2.5, the default I/O scheduling algorithm is Deadline.

trans-unit.source: Beginning from the kernel 2.6.18, CFQ became the default I/O scheduling algorithm.
trans-unit.target: Beginning from the kernel 2.6.18, CFQ became the default I/O scheduling algorithm.

trans-unit.source: You can specify this setting at Kernel boot time or dynamically modify this setting when the system is running.
trans-unit.target: You can specify this setting at Kernel boot time or dynamically modify this setting when the system is running.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to check and set the default scheduler to the NOOP algorithm.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to check and set the default scheduler to the NOOP algorithm.

trans-unit.source: For the Debian distribution family:
trans-unit.target: For the Debian distribution family:

trans-unit.target: Step 1.View the current I/O scheduler

trans-unit.target: Use the following command:

trans-unit.target: You will see following output, which indicates the current scheduler.

trans-unit.source: Step 2. Change the current device (/dev/sda) of I/O scheduling algorithm
trans-unit.target: Step 2. Change the current device (/dev/sda) of I/O scheduling algorithm

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands:

trans-unit.target: Setting this for /dev/sda alone is not useful.

trans-unit.source: It needs to be set on all data disks where the database resides.
trans-unit.target: It needs to be set on all data disks where the database resides.

trans-unit.source: You should see the following output, indicating that grub.cfg has been rebuilt successfully and that the default scheduler has been updated to NOOP.
trans-unit.target: You should see the following output, indicating that grub.cfg has been rebuilt successfully and that the default scheduler has been updated to NOOP.

trans-unit.source: Configure system file operations settings
trans-unit.target: Configure system file operations settings

trans-unit.source: One best practice is to disable the atime logging feature on the file system.
trans-unit.target: One best practice is to disable the atime logging feature on the file system.

trans-unit.source: Atime is the last file access time.
trans-unit.target: Atime is the last file access time.

trans-unit.source: Whenever a file is accessed, the file system records the timestamp in the log.
trans-unit.target: Whenever a file is accessed, the file system records the timestamp in the log.

trans-unit.source: However, this information is rarely used.
trans-unit.target: However, this information is rarely used.

trans-unit.source: You can disable it if you don't need it, which will reduce overall disk access time.
trans-unit.target: You can disable it if you don't need it, which will reduce overall disk access time.

trans-unit.source: To disable atime logging, you need to modify the file system configuration file /etc/ fstab and add the noatime option.
trans-unit.target: To disable atime logging, you need to modify the file system configuration file /etc/ fstab and add the noatime option.

trans-unit.source: For example, edit the vim /etc/fstab file, adding the noatime as shown below.
trans-unit.target: For example, edit the vim /etc/fstab file, adding the noatime as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Then, remount the file system with the following command:
trans-unit.target: Then, remount the file system with the following command:

trans-unit.source: Test the modified result.
trans-unit.target: Test the modified result.

trans-unit.source: Note that when you modify the test file, the access time is not updated.
trans-unit.target: Note that when you modify the test file, the access time is not updated.

trans-unit.source: Before example:
trans-unit.target: Before example:

trans-unit.source: After example:
trans-unit.target: After example:

trans-unit.source: Increase the maximum number of system handles for high concurrency
trans-unit.target: Increase the maximum number of system handles for high concurrency

trans-unit.source: MySQL is high concurrency database.
trans-unit.target: MySQL is high concurrency database.

trans-unit.source: The default number of concurrent handles is 1024 for Linux, which is not always sufficient.
trans-unit.target: The default number of concurrent handles is 1024 for Linux, which is not always sufficient.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to increase the maximum concurrent handles of the system to support high concurrency of MySQL.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to increase the maximum concurrent handles of the system to support high concurrency of MySQL.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Modify the limits.conf file
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Modify the limits.conf file

trans-unit.source: Add the following four lines in the /etc/security/limits.conf file to increase the maximum allowed concurrent handles.
trans-unit.target: Add the following four lines in the /etc/security/limits.conf file to increase the maximum allowed concurrent handles.

trans-unit.source: Note that 65536 is the maximum number that the system can support.
trans-unit.target: Note that 65536 is the maximum number that the system can support.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Update the system for the new limits
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Update the system for the new limits

trans-unit.source: Run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Ensure that the limits are updated at boot time
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Ensure that the limits are updated at boot time

trans-unit.source: Put the following startup commands in the /etc/rc.local file so it will take effect during every boot time.
trans-unit.target: Put the following startup commands in the /etc/rc.local file so it will take effect during every boot time.

trans-unit.source: MySQL database optimization
trans-unit.target: MySQL database optimization

trans-unit.source: You can use the same performance tuning strategy to configure MySQL on Azure as on an on-premises machine.
trans-unit.target: You can use the same performance tuning strategy to configure MySQL on Azure as on an on-premises machine.

trans-unit.source: The main I/O optimization rules are:
trans-unit.target: The main I/O optimization rules are:

trans-unit.source: Increase the cache size.
trans-unit.target: Increase the cache size.

trans-unit.source: Reduce I/O response time.
trans-unit.target: Reduce I/O response time.

trans-unit.source: To optimize MySQL server settings, you can update the my.cnf file, which is the default configuration file for both server and client computers.
trans-unit.target: To optimize MySQL server settings, you can update the my.cnf file, which is the default configuration file for both server and client computers.

trans-unit.source: The following configuration items are the main factors that affect MySQL performance:
trans-unit.target: The following configuration items are the main factors that affect MySQL performance:

trans-unit.source: innodb_buffer_pool_size: The buffer pool contains buffered data and the index.
trans-unit.target: innodb_buffer_pool_size: The buffer pool contains buffered data and the index.

trans-unit.source: This is usually set to 70% of physical memory.
trans-unit.target: This is usually set to 70% of physical memory.

trans-unit.source: innodb_log_file_size: This is the redo log size.
trans-unit.target: innodb_log_file_size: This is the redo log size.

trans-unit.source: You use redo logs to ensure that write operations are fast, reliable, and recoverable after a crash.
trans-unit.target: You use redo logs to ensure that write operations are fast, reliable, and recoverable after a crash.

trans-unit.source: This is set to 512MB, which will give you plenty of space for logging write operations.
trans-unit.target: This is set to 512MB, which will give you plenty of space for logging write operations.

trans-unit.source: max_connections: Sometimes applications do not close connections properly.
trans-unit.target: max_connections: Sometimes applications do not close connections properly.

trans-unit.source: A larger value will give the server more time to recycle idled connections.
trans-unit.target: A larger value will give the server more time to recycle idled connections.

trans-unit.source: The maximum connections is 10000, but the recommended maximum is 5000.
trans-unit.target: The maximum connections is 10000, but the recommended maximum is 5000.

trans-unit.source: Innodb_file_per_table: This setting enable or disable the ability of InnoDB to store tables in separate files. Turn on the option will ensure that several advanced administration operations can be applied efficiently. From performance point of view, it can speed up the table space transmission and optimize the debris management performance. So the recommended setting for this is ON.
trans-unit.target: Innodb_file_per_table: This setting enable or disable the ability of InnoDB to store tables in separate files. Turn on the option will ensure that several advanced administration operations can be applied efficiently. From performance point of view, it can speed up the table space transmission and optimize the debris management performance. So the recommended setting for this is ON.

trans-unit.source: From MySQL 5.6, the default setting is ON.
trans-unit.target: From MySQL 5.6, the default setting is ON.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, no action is required.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, no action is required.

trans-unit.source: For other versions, which is earlier than 5.6, default settings is OFF.
trans-unit.target: For other versions, which is earlier than 5.6, default settings is OFF.

trans-unit.source: Turning this ON is required.
trans-unit.target: Turning this ON is required.

trans-unit.source: And should apply it before data is loaded, because only newly-created tables are affected.
trans-unit.target: And should apply it before data is loaded, because only newly-created tables are affected.

trans-unit.source: innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit: Default value is 1, with the scope set to 0~2.
trans-unit.target: innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit: Default value is 1, with the scope set to 0~2.

trans-unit.source: The default value is the most suitable option for standalone MySQL DB.
trans-unit.target: The default value is the most suitable option for standalone MySQL DB.

trans-unit.source: The setting of 2 enables the most data integrity and is suitable for Master in MySQL cluster.
trans-unit.target: The setting of 2 enables the most data integrity and is suitable for Master in MySQL cluster.

trans-unit.source: The setting of 0 allows data loss, which can affect reliability, in some cases with better performance, and is suitable for Slave in MySQL cluster.
trans-unit.target: The setting of 0 allows data loss, which can affect reliability, in some cases with better performance, and is suitable for Slave in MySQL cluster.

trans-unit.source: Innodb_log_buffer_size: The log buffer allows transactions to run without having to flush the log to disk before the transactions commit.
trans-unit.target: Innodb_log_buffer_size: The log buffer allows transactions to run without having to flush the log to disk before the transactions commit.

trans-unit.source: However, if there is large binary object or text field, the cache will be consumed very quickly and frequent disk I/O will be triggered.
trans-unit.target: However, if there is large binary object or text field, the cache will be consumed very quickly and frequent disk I/O will be triggered.

trans-unit.source: It is better increase the buffer size if Innodb_log_waits state variable is not 0.
trans-unit.target: It is better increase the buffer size if Innodb_log_waits state variable is not 0.

trans-unit.source: query_cache_size: The best option is to disable it from the outset.
trans-unit.target: query_cache_size: The best option is to disable it from the outset.

trans-unit.source: Set query_cache_size to 0 (this is now the default setting in MySQL 5.6) and use other methods to speed up queries .
trans-unit.target: Set query_cache_size to 0 (this is now the default setting in MySQL 5.6) and use other methods to speed up queries .

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Appendix D</linkText><title></title></link> for comparing performance after the optimization.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Appendix D</linkText><title></title></link> for comparing performance after the optimization.

trans-unit.source: Turn on the MySQL slow query log for analyzing the performance bottleneck
trans-unit.target: Turn on the MySQL slow query log for analyzing the performance bottleneck

trans-unit.source: The MySQL slow query log can help you identify the slow queries for MySQL.
trans-unit.target: The MySQL slow query log can help you identify the slow queries for MySQL.

trans-unit.source: After enabling the MySQL slow query log, you can use MySQL tools like mysqldumpslow to identify the performance bottleneck.
trans-unit.target: After enabling the MySQL slow query log, you can use MySQL tools like mysqldumpslow to identify the performance bottleneck.

trans-unit.source: Please note that by default this is not enabled.
trans-unit.target: Please note that by default this is not enabled.

trans-unit.source: Turning on the slow query log may consume some CPU resources.
trans-unit.target: Turning on the slow query log may consume some CPU resources.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it is recommended that you enable this temporarily for troubleshooting performance bottlenecks.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it is recommended that you enable this temporarily for troubleshooting performance bottlenecks.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Modify my.cnf file by adding the following lines to the end
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Modify my.cnf file by adding the following lines to the end

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Restart mysql server
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Restart mysql server

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Check whether the setting is taking effect using the “show” command
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Check whether the setting is taking effect using the “show” command

trans-unit.source: In this example, you can see that the slow query feature has been turned on.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you can see that the slow query feature has been turned on.

trans-unit.source: You can then use the mysqldumpslow tool to determine performance bottlenecks and optimize performance, such as adding indexes.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the mysqldumpslow tool to determine performance bottlenecks and optimize performance, such as adding indexes.
